author: By Lior Phillips
title: Desire Marea’s Genre-Melting Music Stirs South Africa, and the World
description: The 32-year-old’s work in Zulu and English traverses styles and explores queer histories. This week he releases a new EP, “The Baddies of Isandlwana.”
content: On a crisp Thursday morning hours before Desire Marea’s performance at the Transform Festival in Leeds, England, earlier this month, the South African songwriter sat in Kirkstall Valley Nature Reserve, communing with his Zulu ancestors. It’s a practice he honed through his training as a sangoma, a traditional spiritual healer, and it is essential to his craft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: Mississippi: How to Vote, Where to Vote and What’s on the Ballot
description: The state’s Republican governor, Tate Reeves, is facing a credible threat from his Democratic challenger, Brandon Presley.
content: [Here’s how to vote in Ohio, New York, New Jersey, Kentucky, and Virginia.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Is Homer Simpson a Good Dad Now?
description: In a recent episode of “The Simpsons,” Homer suggested he would abandon one of his best-known bits: throttling his son. It is the latest example of the show tailoring itself to evolving tastes.
content: Homer Simpson may be maturing, or so he says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: ‘Black Panther’ Stuntman and 3 Children Die in Georgia Car Crash
description: The stuntman, Taraja Ramsess, worked on dozens of other films, including “Bad Boys for Life” and “The Suicide Squad.”
content: Taraja Ramsess, a stunt performer who worked on the “Black Panther” and “Avengers” Marvel franchises, died in a car crash near Atlanta last week that also killed three of his children, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Amjad Iraqi
description: The Nov. 7, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Amjad Iraqi. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: 5 Things We Learned During Trump’s Trial Testimony
description: The former president took the witness stand Monday in a Manhattan courtroom as he tried to preserve the business empire that made his name.
content: Donald J. Trump took the witness stand on Monday in a packed New York courtroom in a trial that threatens the business empire underpinning his public persona as he kicks off another run for the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: It’s Election Day in New York: Here’s What to Know
description: Although no citywide offices are being contested this year, the New York City Council is up for election, and voters statewide will consider two ballot questions.
content: [Here’s how to vote in New Jersey, Ohio, Mississippi, Kentucky, and Virginia.]
source.name: The New York Times

title: 7 New Songs You Should Hear Now
description: Listen to tracks by Brittany Howard, Hauschka, boygenius and more.
content: For some people, early November heralds the beginning of the holiday season. But for music critics and fans, it’s the beginning of an entirely different, equally frantic season: time to start working on “Best of the Year” lists and checking them (at least) twice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Gary Colson, Who Lobbied for 3-Point Shot in College Ball, Dies at 89
description: On a rules committee, he got fellow coaches to vote for the shot that changed the game. In 34 years as a college coach, he won 563 games with four teams.
content: Gary Colson, who successfully lobbied to introduce the 3-point shot to college basketball during a 34-year coaching career that included stops at Fresno State, New Mexico and Pepperdine, died on Friday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: At the Noortwyck, an Eleven Madison Park Chef Gets Neighborly
description: In his Greenwich Village kitchen, Andrew Quinn finds the middle ground between grandeur and informality.
content: For years, one of Eleven Madison Park’s favorite party tricks has been inviting diners midway through the meal to have a drink in the kitchen. If you accept, you will be led to a spot against the back wall behind a shallow ledge that looks something like a communion rail. There you stand as an elaborate cocktail is mixed, narrated and poured. You get to check out the cooks at their stations, and they get to check you out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Conditions
description: Kevin Curry and Daniel Bodily tee up their first collaboration for The New York Times.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Wu
title: In Regulating A.I., We May Be Doing Too Much. And Too Little.
description: Success will mean staying focused on concrete problems like deep fakes.
content: When President Biden signed his sweeping executive order on artificial intelligence last week, he joked about the strange experience of watching a “deep fake” of himself, saying, “When the hell did I say that?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Room-Temperature Superconductor Discovery Is Retracted
description: It was the second paper led by Ranga P. Dias, a researcher at the University of Rochester, that the journal Nature has retracted.
content: Nature, one of the most prestigious journals in scientific publishing, on Tuesday retracted a high-profile paper it had published in March that claimed the discovery of a superconductor that worked at everyday temperatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
title: Under Scrutiny Over Gaza, Israel Points to Civilian Toll of U.S. Wars
description: Israeli officials say it is impossible to defeat Hamas without killing innocents, a lesson they argue Americans and their allies should understand.
content: Falluja. Mosul. Copenhagen. Hiroshima.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: A Win and a Warning Ahead of COP28
description: Tensions between rich and poor countries are on display.
content: Last year, the annual United Nations climate talks ended with a landmark agreement to compensate poor countries for destruction from climate disasters that have been made worse by emissions from wealthy nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: How Can ‘Absurd’ Luxury Prices be Justified?
description: The exorbitant cost of luxury fashion has left us out in the cold, wondering who can sustain this market?
content: Historically, luxury fashion brands have enjoyed strong pricing power, meaning that they can apply considerable increases without necessarily losing customers. But in 2023, price tags hit eye-watering highs — and there has been no sign of the trend slowing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
title: ‘Something Was Wrong’: Ukrainians Lament Deaths at Medal Ceremony
description: A gathering in plain sight of so many soldiers was reckless, critics said, and evoked a rigid adherence to Soviet-era military tradition.
content: The family of Major Serhiy Kuznyev sensed something was wrong. He was not answering his phone. Officers in his unit refused to provide information on him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Karen Zraick, Victoria Kim and Michael Levenson
title: Israel Plans to Control ‘Overall Security’ of Gaza After War
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel would be at risk of another major attack if it did not remain engaged in the Palestinian enclave.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has offered the clearest indication to date about what Israel may be planning for the aftermath of the war in the Gaza Strip, warning that it will need to oversee “overall security” there once the fighting is over to prevent future attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Ruth Igielnik and Camille Baker
title: What’s Behind Kennedy’s Poll Numbers? Voters Dread a Trump-Biden Rematch.
description: Frustration with the two men likely to be the major parties’ nominees has led voters to entertain the idea of other options, New York Times/Siena College polls found.
content: A looming rematch next year between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump has left voters deeply dissatisfied with their options, longing for alternatives and curious about independent candidates like Robert F. Kennedy Jr., according to new polls of six battleground states conducted by The New York Times and Siena College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: Nearing Her 109th Birthday, and Still Waiting for Her Day in Court
description: Lessie Benningfield Randle survived the Tulsa race massacre of 1921. Her lawyers are making what they say is a final bid to keep her case alive.
content: For more than a century, Lessie Benningfield Randle, one of the last known survivors of the 1921 Tulsa race massacre, has lived with the searing details of that spring. For decades, she has recalled the fire that ravaged her neighborhood, Greenwood, and the frantic trip with her grandmother to the safety of a fairground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Automakers Delay Electric Vehicle Spending as Demand Slows
description: Growth is brisk but slower than expected, causing automakers to question their multibillion-dollar investments in new factories and raising doubts about the effectiveness of federal incentives.
content: Normally a 50 percent increase in sales is considered very good. But when the number of electric vehicles sold in the United States grew that much during the third quarter from a year earlier, it was a disappointment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Cheng and Sharon Radisch
title: How the Humble Sheet Cake Became Top Tier
description: In the world of special occasion baked goods, pastry chefs are embracing the birthday party staple for its vast canvas.
content: The Los Angeles-based baker Michelle Boulos can still picture the sheet cakes she ate as a child: slathered with bright white frosting, decorated with tiny plastic balloons. But the confections she makes and sells via her Instagram account No Good Cakes are something else entirely. On one recent creation, frills of buttercream surrounded an acid green ombré surface inspired by a chemical spill. On another, foraged blooms sprouted from bronze-colored barnacles, some of them embedded with tiny light bulbs. Boulos, 34, started baking the fantastical cakes out of her home in 2022 after making one for a wedding. “I got bitten by the sheet cake bug,” she says. “It can be so versatile but also really complex.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: The death toll in Gaza climbs.
content: Nearly a month after Israel began its bombardment of Gaza, the territory’s Hamas-run health ministry said more than 10,000 people had been killed and more than 25,000 injured. The figures could not be independently verified, but a Pentagon spokesman said that “we know the numbers are in the thousands.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Does the Right Hate America?
description: In many ways, social change has made us a better nation.
content: U.S. democracy is clearly in crisis. It’s entirely possible that in less than two years dissenters will face the power of a government with an authoritarian bent; if that sounds to you like hyperbole, you aren’t paying attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler
title: Jewish Man’s Death After California Protest Clash Is Under Investigation
description: The episode occurred in a suburb outside Los Angeles amid pro-Israel and pro-Palestinian demonstrations.
content: As a fatal clash between suburban protesters in Southern California threatened to become an international incident on Tuesday, the authorities said that it wasn’t “exactly crystal clear” how a 69-year-old Jewish man died from an altercation with a pro-Palestinian demonstrator over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Alexandra Stevenson
title: China’s Banks and Property Sector Threaten a Growing Economy
description: The International Monetary Fund warned of risks from overstretched lenders and developers even as it raised economic growth forecasts for this year and next.
content: The International Monetary Fund warned on Tuesday of risks posed by China’s financial and property sectors even as it took a more optimistic view on the country’s economic growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Why Salmonella Makes So Many People Sick
description: The bacteria are a leading cause of food poisoning. Here’s how to avoid an infection.
content: Diced onions, cookie dough, flour, alfalfa sprouts, peanut butter — what do these very different foods have in common?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse
title: House Republicans Toil for a Spending Strategy With a Shutdown Close at Hand
description: Speaker Mike Johnson is facing many of the same challenges his predecessor did as he looks for a way to avoid a government shutdown that will be acceptable to his deeply divided conference.
content: House Republicans on Tuesday grasped for a way to avert a government shutdown amid deep divides in their ranks over federal spending, debating how to strike a compromise with the Democratic-led Senate and President Biden just 10 days away from the funding deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Time Change
description: Do you look forward to “falling back” an hour — or dread it?
content: Sunday marked the end of Daylight Saving Time, where, in some parts of the world, including the United States, people set their clocks back an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Biggest Winner at the Oscars of American Fashion
description: The C.F.D.A. awards weren’t dominated by a single designer, but by an idea.
content: How political should fashion get? At least when it comes to acceptance speeches. That was the elephant — or woolly mammoth, or orca — in the room Monday night at the Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, a.k.a. the Oscars of fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Orcas Sink Fourth Boat Off Iberia, Unnerving Sailors
description: Orcas caused enough damage to sink a yacht in the Strait of Gibraltar last week. A small pod has been slamming boats in recent years, worrying skippers chartering routes closer to shore.
content: The yacht Grazie Mamma II carried its crew along the coastlines and archipelagos of the Mediterranean. Its last adventure was off the coast of Morocco last week, when it encountered a pod of orcas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Litovsky and Jon Mooallem
title: Their Final Wish? A Burial in Space.
description: Why some people decide to send their remains into orbit.
content: There are two ways to contemplate the question Where do we go when we die? One is philosophical, ultimately unanswerable; the other is logistical. Humans, being human, have tended to see them as being intertwined: The many traditions we’ve devised for handling our remains are meant to honor the selves that left those bodies behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Viewed Warily by Democrats, a Netanyahu Ally Is a Key Conduit to U.S.
description: Ron Dermer sits in Israel’s five-member war cabinet and is a crucial liaison to the Biden administration, including U.S. officials he clashed with when he was ambassador to Washington.
content: When Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu named Ron Dermer as Israel’s ambassador to the United States in 2013, aides to President Barack Obama, viewing Mr. Dermer as a right-wing political operative rather than a diplomat, discussed whether the White House should refuse to accept his credentials. (They dropped the idea.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Rivals Battle Each Other, and His Aura of Inevitability, as Next Debate Approaches
description: Donald Trump’s Republican challengers find themselves fighting a growing sense of resignation that 2024 will be a rematch of 2020.
content: The 2024 Republican presidential race is entering a fraught and caustic new phase, as Donald J. Trump’s wide lead remains undiminished, the days until voting begins dwindle and his rivals take aim at each other as much as at him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Flaco the Owl, Zoo Escapee, Leaves Central Park for the East Village
description: Nine months after settling into a new life in the park, Flaco turned up about five miles away on a tree branch in a sculpture garden.
content: Flaco the Eurasian eagle-owl, whose February escape from the Central Park Zoo captured the public’s attention in New York and beyond, turned up in Manhattan’s East Village on Monday, about five miles from the wooded park area he had settled into since flying free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Su
title: Did a 2008 Rule Change Ruin Presidential Debates?
description: Presidential candidates’s meetings weren’t always so hostile.
content: Sophomoric insults. Rudeness. Personal attacks. Cross talk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Human Skull, On Sale for $4,000, Draws Attention to Florida Store
description: A Halloween display at a rock and crystal store in North Fort Myers brought scrutiny after an anthropologist told the authorities that the remains appeared to be of a Native American.
content: As a nod to Halloween, Beth Meyer, who owns a rock and crystal store in North Fort Myers, Fla., placed a human skull inside a glass display case there and surrounded it with quartz towers and other crystals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Did So Many Economists Get Disinflation Wrong?
description: The good news shouldn’t have been such a big surprise.
content: The Brookings Papers on Economic Activity, a conference held twice a year, is America’s premier forum for relating academic research to “the most urgent economic challenges of the day.” The lead presentation at the September 2022 conference was a paper by Laurence Ball, Daniel Leigh and Prachi Mishra on inflation. And its conclusions were dismal. Harvard’s Jason Furman, one of the assigned discussants, wrote an opinion piece calling it “the scariest economics paper of 2022,” suggesting that to get inflation down to 2 percent “we may need to tolerate unemployment of 6.5 percent for two years.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Snatch Adams’ Review: Gross-Out Humor for Not-So-Easily-Shocked Liberals
description: Becca Blackwell and Amanda Duarte’s amorphous variety show aims to be a queer spectacle but is mostly improv strung together with non sequiturs.
content: The usually unassuming Soho Rep entrance is now flanked by giant labia glinting with gold-and-fuchsia sequins. Beyond them, a flamingo-pink-hued tunnel leads to the intimate stage, where a colossal pair of brassy legs are splayed as if for a gynecological exam in an amusement park fun house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Hammer
title: Grave Robbers of the Wild West
description: In “Sins of the Shovel,” Rachel Morgan describes the dark, chaotic early days of American archaeology.
content: Archaeology in its formative years was often less a meticulous science than an exercise in vandalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Fire Destroys World War II-Era Blimp Hangar in California
description: The structure was built in 1942 to house blimps that patrolled the California coastline, watching for enemy submarines.
content: A fire was consuming a wooden blimp hangar on Tuesday in Tustin, Calif., that played a pivotal role during World War II, the authorities said, causing the landmark to crumble in flames throughout the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Gaia Pianigiani
title: Italian Officials Question Meloni’s Deal With Albania to House Migrants
description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy says that outsourcing the processing and containment of migrants is a breakthrough model for Europe. Politicians question if it is legal, ethical or practical.
content: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy on Tuesday heralded an agreement she had struck with Albania, a non-European Union nation, to outsource the processing and containment of migrants as a breakthrough for one of the continent’s most defining challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Winter Accessories That Sparkle and Shine
description: Sequins, paillettes and rhinestones light up this season’s shoes and bags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Taking Note as Dance Reflections Takes a Pause
description: It has its ups and downs, but this festival, presented by Van Cleef & Arpels, brings a wealth of experimental dance to New York City.
content: Dance Reflections, a festival dedicated to choreographic innovation, is not ready to wrap yet: It picks up again next week with a collaboration between the choreographer Dimitri Chamblas and the musician Kim Gordon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: The Ad Wars Have Been Fierce. Here’s What Voters Have Seen.
description: Tens of millions of dollars have been pumped into today’s elections, in a sign of their national implications.
content: Tens of millions of dollars have poured into television advertising in the four states with major elections on Tuesday, a sign of the national implications of their outcomes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and J. Edward Moreno
title: WeWork Files for Bankruptcy Amid Glut of Empty Offices
description: The move is a blow for landlords who have rented space to the co-working group, which is planning a “comprehensive reorganization” that includes cutting some of its leases.
content: WeWork, the real estate company that offered start-ups and individuals sleek quarters to pursue their entrepreneurial dreams, filed for bankruptcy protection in the United States on Monday after years of struggling to find its footing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Mel Sembler, Developer and G.O.P. Fund-Raiser, Is Dead at 93
description: He received ambassadorships after filling campaign coffers that led to two Bush presidencies. He later came around to backing Donald Trump.
content: Mel Sembler, a gregarious developer and major Republican fund-raiser whose largess was repaid with prize ambassadorships by two presidents, and who founded a controversy-courting “tough love” drug rehabilitation program, died on Oct. 31 at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Wang
title: In ‘The Future,’ Earth Barrels Toward Fiery Destruction
description: Naomi Alderman’s new novel imagines an end of the world that only the wealthiest can survive — or can they?
content: There are few figures in the Bible more cruelly evocative than Lot’s wife, who is transfigured into a pillar of salt for looking back at Sodom. The poet Anna Akhmatova mourned “her swift legs rooted to the ground”; Kurt Vonnegut wrote of her backward glance, “I love her for that, because it was so human.” Naomi Alderman’s “The Future,” like much great science fiction, turns the symbolic into tangible, chemical reality. Early in her novel, a woman is frozen to death with a chemical refrigerant made of paramagnetic salts: a Lot’s wife for the Information Age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: I Just Got Over Covid but Still Feel Awful
description: Symptoms can linger for days or weeks after testing negative, even for those who don’t develop long Covid.
content: Q: It’s been a week since I tested negative for Covid, but I don’t feel totally better. Why am I still sick?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Christina Anderson
title: Workers in Sweden Will Expand Strike Against Tesla
description: Swedish unions are joining in blockades and targeted strikes against the U.S. automaker over its refusal to sign a collective bargaining agreement with its mechanics.
content: Unions across Sweden said on Tuesday that they would support an effort to pressure Tesla to sign a collective bargaining agreement with its 120 mechanics, joining a campaign to defend a model of organized labor that many Swedes say is essential to the country’s economic success and stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick, Vivian Yee and Emma Bubola
title: As War Closes In, Many Remain in Northern Gaza
description: Hundreds of thousands of people are still in the region, despite Israel’s bombing, ground invasion and evacuation directive. Many say the trip to the south is too dangerous.
content: They knew it would be perilous, but Jinan Al Salya and her family decided to heed Israeli directions to evacuate the northern Gaza Strip and head south. They hadn’t gone far on Saturday, she said, when they came under fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Simonson
title: He Believes He’s Been Reincarnated. Here’s His Tale of Life, Love and Fate.
description: In Jonathan Evison’s new novel, “Again and Again,” a curmudgeonly old man in an elder-care facility finds an unlikely connection as he recounts the stories of his past lives.
content: It is “the most beautiful of all possible worlds,” a chapter heading proclaims at the beginning of Jonathan Evison’s new novel, “Again and Again.” But it’s easy to doubt this cheerful echo of “Candide” as we are introduced to the book’s protagonist, Eugene Miles, a centenarian curmudgeon living in an elder-care facility in the California desert who insists — a bit too loudly and often — on his desire to be left alone to await death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kravitz Hoeffner and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: What New York Voters Care About: Migrants and the High Cost of Living
description: With no statewide races on the ballot, attention was on competitive City Council races, especially in South Brooklyn and parts of the Bronx.
content: From Brooklyn to the Bronx, voters across New York City trickled into polling sites on Tuesday, after a morning workout or during their lunch breaks, to cast ballots in races for City Council, district attorney and other local offices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Thousands of Gazans fled south during a window given by Israel, the U.N. says.
description: About 5,000 people left the northern half of Gaza during a four-hour window given by the Israeli military on Monday, according to United Nations monitors, a day after Israel said its forces had cleaved the territory in two.
content: About 5,000 people left the northern half of Gaza during a four-hour window given by the Israeli military on Monday, according to United Nations monitors, a day after Israel said its forces had cleaved the territory in two.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: ‘Vortenses’ and the Storms of Space-Time
description: In verse and in color, a Nobel physicist and a visual artist collaborate to portray black holes, gravitational waves and other preposterous features of Einstein’s universe.
content: If you have ever wondered what it might feel like to be sucked into a black hole — twisted, stretched, confused, doomed — you could do worse than trip through “The Warped Side of Our Universe, An Odyssey Through Black Holes, Wormholes, Time Travel and Gravitational Waves,” a collaborative book project by Kip Thorne, a physicist at the California Institute of Technology, and Lia Halloran, a visual artist and chair of the art department at Chapman University in Orange, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: N.F.L. Fans, Take a Number for Your Team’s Chances
description: The Upshot’s N.F.L. Playoff Simulator is churning out options for the 10th straight year.
content: There are some drawbacks to being a Minnesota Vikings fan, said Kevin Quealy, editor of The Upshot, The New York Times’s data-driven site about politics, economics and everyday life. His team has never won the Super Bowl, and just trying to calculate their playoff odds can become a headache. Even sportscasters appear to be run ragged by the probabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden Confronts the Limits of U.S. Leverage in Two Conflicts
description: President Biden’s influence over Israel and Ukraine seems far more constrained than expected, given his central role as the supplier of arms and intelligence.
content: After four weeks of terror and retaliation in Israel and Gaza, and 20 months of war in Ukraine, President Biden is confronting the limits of his leverage in the two international conflicts defining his presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Here’s Who Qualified for the Third Republican Presidential Debate
description: Chris Christie, Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, Vivek Ramaswamy and Tim Scott will meet again on the stage on Wednesday night, but Doug Burgum missed the cut.
content: Five candidates have qualified for the third Republican presidential debate on Wednesday evening, the Republican National Committee announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: House Censures Rashida Tlaib, Citing ‘River to the Sea’ Slogan
description: Twenty-two Democrats joined most Republicans in the rebuke of Ms. Tlaib, the only Palestinian American in Congress, accusing her of calling for the destruction of Israel.
content: The House voted on Tuesday to censure Representative Rashida Tlaib, Democrat of Michigan, formally rebuking the sole Palestinian American in Congress for her statements regarding the Israel-Hamas war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Gaza Death Toll Has Hit 10,000, Its Health Ministry Says
description: The figures could not be independently verified, but a Pentagon spokesman acknowledged on Monday that “we know the numbers are in the thousands.”
content: In just under a month, Israeli strikes have killed more than 10,000 people in Gaza and injured more than 25,000 others, the Gaza Health Ministry said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Why Palestinians Feel Like They’ve Been ‘Duped’
description: The Palestinian policy analyst and writer Amjad Iraqi on how Gaza’s past, present and future look from his eyes.
content: Before there can be any kind of stable coexistence of people in Israel and Palestine, there will have to be a stable coexistence of narratives. And that’s what we’ll be attempting this week on the show: to look at both the present and the past through Israeli and Palestinian perspectives. The point is not to choose between them. The point is to really listen to them. Even — especially — when what’s being said is hard for us to hear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson, Adam Entous and Andrés R. Martínez
title: Israel Says It Has Split Gaza Strip in Two in Drive to Isolate Hamas’s Leadership
description: Israel’s military surrounded Gaza City as the enclave plunged into another communications blackout, sowing panic among relatives fearful of the fate of loved ones who remain there.
content: The Israeli military said its forces had split the Gaza Strip in two after a night of heavy airstrikes, a move that Israel said would make it more difficult for Hamas to control the enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: King Charles III, Climate Advocate, Delivers Speech at Odds With His Beliefs
description: In keeping with tradition, he outlined the priorities of the prime minister at the opening of Parliament — including, this year, more fossil fuel extraction.
content: For a lifelong supporter of environmental causes, a plan to expand oil and gas drilling in the North Sea was probably not what King Charles III had hoped to announce when he opened Britain’s Parliament for the first time as monarch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: onus
description: This word has appeared in 83 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word onus has appeared in 83 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 23 in the Opinion essay “We’re Teaching Music to Kids All Wrong” by Sammy Miller:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Schools Curb Grade Inflation?
description: Readers respond to an Opinion essay arguing that only exceptional students should get A’s. Also: Hernia operations; pedestrian safety.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Wildfires Burn for Days in Southern U.S. States
description: Firefighters in several states have been fighting to contain blazes that have primarily been fueled by severe drought and warmer temperatures.
content: Wildfires caused by drought, warmer-than-normal temperatures and, in a few cases, possibly arson have been ablaze for days in several Southern states. The threat has led officials to enact burn bans and to stop issuing safe-burn permits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Infants Are Born With Syphilis in Growing Numbers, a Sign of a Wider Epidemic
description: Congenital syphilis has become more than ten times as common over the past decade, the C.D.C. reported. “The situation is dire,” said one expert.
content: The rise in sexually transmitted infections in the United States has taken a particularly tragic turn: More than 3,700 cases of congenital syphilis were reported in 2022, roughly 11 times the number recorded a decade ago, according to data released on Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Portugal’s Prime Minister Resigns Unexpectedly
description: He quit shortly after prosecutors announced raids on government buildings as part of an investigation into corruption.
content: Prime Minister António Costa of Portugal resigned unexpectedly on Tuesday, hours after the police raided government buildings as part of an inquiry into corruption and “influence peddling” and issued an arrest warrant for Mr. Costa’s chief of staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: A Guide to Election Day
description: Can a Democrat win the Deep South? And other questions to help you make sense of the results.
content: Today is Election Day, and we are using this newsletter to give you a guide. One theme is that Democrats are hoping to continue their strong recent electoral performance despite President Biden’s low approval rating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: More Than 20 Report Burning Eyes After NFT Festival in Hong Kong
description: Bored Ape Yacht Club, the collective that hosted the three-day event, said it was investigating possible causes, including UV lights used at a party on Saturday night.
content: More than 20 people have reported burning eye pain and vision problems after attending a party for NFT owners in Hong Kong last weekend, the organizers said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Senate Confirms Biden’s Pick for N.I.H. Director Over Sanders’s Objections
description: Dr. Monica M. Bertagnolli won bipartisan approval despite opposition from Senator Bernie Sanders, the chairman of the Senate health committee.
content: The Senate on Tuesday confirmed Dr. Monica M. Bertagnolli, a cancer surgeon who currently leads the National Cancer Institute, as the next director of the National Institutes of Health, overriding the objections of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, the chairman of the Senate health committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: It’s Election Day in New Jersey: Here’s What to Know
description: All of the seats in the State Legislature are on the ballot, and Republicans are hoping to make gains.
content: [Here’s how to vote in Ohio, New York, Mississippi, Kentucky, and Virginia.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Riffs on Trump’s Lead Over Biden in Early Poll
description: “Polling a year ahead of an election is always super-accurate — and if you don’t believe me, just ask President Hillary Clinton,” Jimmy Kimmel said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Reoccupying Gaza ‘Not the Right Thing to Do,’ White House Tells Israel
description: The U.S. caution came after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu floated the idea that Israel might oversee security for the Gaza Strip indefinitely.
content: The White House cautioned Israel on Tuesday against reoccupying Gaza after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu suggested that his country could hold a security role there “for an indefinite period” once the war is over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Should Schools Ban Cellphones?
description: Rules restricting when students can use phones are on the rise. Do they work? Are they fair?
content: Nearly one in four countries has laws or policies banning or restricting student cellphone use in schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech, Ryn Jirenuwat and Muktita Suhartono
title: Thailand hopes its hostages in Gaza will be the next to be released.
description: Thai officials have seen photos of the hostages who were abducted on Oct. 7 in southern Israel.
content: The foreign minister of Thailand said Tuesday that officials he had met in Qatar and Egypt indicated the Thai hostages held by Hamas and other armed groups would be the next to be released because they had nothing to do with the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Volner
title: The Rise and Fall and Rise of San Francisco
description: Two books — “The Longest Minute,” by Matthew J. Davenport, and “Portal,” by John King — examine the City by the Bay’s resiliency from very different angles.
content: Beset, on the one hand, by starry-eyed admirers, and on the other, by doom-and-gloom detractors, San Francisco has become a political hockey puck, slapped around with little regard for its actual qualities. Two very engaging new books attempt to give the city its due, presenting it not as an abstraction but as a place — albeit a very dramatic one, swinging precipitously between crisis and rebirth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Barry Manilow Finally Gets His Wish: a Broadway Show
description: “Harmony,” about a singing group undone by Nazism, has been a decades-in-the-making labor of love for the singer and his longtime collaborator Bruce Sussman.
content: Barry Manilow is superstitious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Carlos Prieto, Stella Tan, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Devon Taylor, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Growing Republican Battle Over War Funding
description: Speaker Mike Johnson, who has opposed continued funding for Ukraine, is now insisting on separating it from aid to Israel.
content: It’s been one month since the attack on Israel, but Washington has yet to deliver an aid package to its closest ally. The reason has to do with a different ally, in a different war: Speaker Mike Johnson has opposed continued funding for Ukraine, and wants the issue separated from aid to Israel, setting up a clash between the House and Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Does Anyone Know How to Behave on the Subway Anymore?
description: New Yorkers are reacquainting themselves with the subway code — no eye contact; no stinky food — as the city rebounds from the coronavirus pandemic.
content: There are unwritten rules when riding the New York City subway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Setting a Table for the Holidays? Designers Share Their Secrets.
description: For starters, don’t worry if there isn’t much space: “The closer the people are, the better the party.”
content: Serving a meal is about more than just feeding your guests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley
title: Lavish Tax Credits and Trade Protections Lure Solar Firms to U.S.
description: A combination of government policies is finally succeeding in reversing a long decline in solar manufacturing in the United States.
content: Six years ago, an executive from Suniva, a bankrupt solar panel manufacturer, warned a packed hearing room in Washington that competition from companies in China and Southeast Asia was causing a “blood bath” in his industry. More than 30 U.S.-based solar companies had been forced to shut down in the previous five years alone, he said, and others would soon follow unless the government supported them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Soltis Anderson
title: Step 1 if You’re Going to Beat Trump
description: His opponents have to take him on with sustained attacks that don’t alienate his supporters. There’s a right approach and a wrong approach.
content: In the movie “Back to the Future II,” Michael J. Fox’s character, Marty McFly, is transported to the fall of 2015 and encounters a world of self-tying shoes and hoverboards. He finds himself trying to make sense of how people behave and the choices they make.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: What to Watch for in Today’s Elections, and More
description: Plus, a gun rights case at the Supreme Court and WeWork’s bankruptcy filing.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A Report Card for Bidenomics
description: Voters’ negative perceptions about the economy are weighing on President Biden’s poll numbers. Here’s what his economic policies have, and haven’t, accomplished.
content: With a year to go before Election Day, polls increasingly show that American voters believe next year will be a rematch between President Biden and Donald Trump — with the former president in the lead in key battleground states despite his legal troubles (more on that below).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: Ohio: How to Vote, Where to Vote and What’s on the Ballot
description: On Election Day, voters in Ohio will decide on two ballot measures: one on abortion rights and one on the recreational use of marijuana.
content: [Here’s how to vote in New Jersey, New York, Mississippi, Kentucky, and Virginia.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Jean-Baptiste Andrea Wins Goncourt Prize With Sprawling Novel
description: The prestigious French literary award went to “Watching Over Her,” or “Veiller Sur Elle,” an almost 600-page novel set in 20th-century Italy.
content: Jean-Baptiste Andrea received the Goncourt Prize, France’s most prestigious literary award, on Tuesday for his novel “Watching Over Her,” or “Veiller Sur Elle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Cyberattack Disrupts Mortgage Payments for Millions of Mr. Cooper Customers
description: The company, one of the largest U.S. mortgage servicers, said it was trying to determine if the attackers obtained personal information about its four million customers.
content: Mr. Cooper, one of America’s largest nonbank mortgage loan servicers, suffered a cyberattack last week that disrupted loan payments and other transactions for millions of customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Hungry (but Not for Human Contact), Americans Head for the Drive-Through
description: A national fixture is enjoying a fresh surge as post-pandemic customers crave speed and solitude. And restaurants are responding with a raft of innovations.
content: Faith Enokian loves a drive-through. The senior at the University of South Alabama loves them so much she pulls into one at least eight times a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida Dentist Convicted in Murder-for-Hire Plot Against Law Professor
description: A jury in Tallahassee found Charles Adelson guilty of murder and conspiracy in the 2014 death of his former brother-in-law, Dan Markel.
content: For nearly a decade, the sensational killing of a prominent Florida law professor in 2014 centered on a single, sordid question: Did his ex-wife’s family, motivated by an ugly custody dispute, hire hit men to murder him?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: Virginia: How to Vote, Where to Vote and What’s on the Ballot
description: All 140 seats in Virginia’s General Assembly are on the ballot, and Republicans led by Gov. Glenn Youngkin are seeking full control of the state government.
content: [Here’s how to vote in Ohio, New York, New Jersey, Mississippi, and Kentucky.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: Ohio Is Voting on Whether to Establish Abortion Rights
description: The outcome is being closely watched by Democrats and Republicans looking to measure the strength of voter anger over the loss of federal abortion protections.
content: Ohio voters are deciding on a ballot measure that would amend the state’s Constitution to explicitly guarantee the right to abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: Barbra Streisand Is Ready to Tell All. Pull Up a Seat.
description: At home in California, Streisand talks about her new memoir, exploring the movies and men of her life, and her determination to control her own art.
content: Maybe it’s her grandkids, maybe it’s being 81, but Barbra Streisand is open to new stuff. Take sharing. Well, take sharing herself. “My Name Is Barbra,” her first memoir, is upon us. It’s 970 pages and billows with doubt, anger, ardor, hurt, pride, persuasion, glory and Yiddish. I don’t know that any artist has done more sharing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: California Boat Captain Convicted of Manslaughter in Fire That Killed 34
description: The 2019 fire near Santa Barbara killed all 33 passengers of the dive boat. On Monday, a federal jury found the captain guilty of “seaman’s manslaughter.”
content: The captain of a dive boat that caught fire off the coast of Southern California in 2019, killing all 33 passengers and one of its six crew members, was found guilty by a federal jury on Monday on one count of an offense known as “seaman’s manslaughter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: Extreme Weather May Be Displacing Animals, Too, a New Study Suggests
description: An analysis by researchers in China found that weather disasters might be helping nonnative animals replace native species in the wild.
content: A new analysis published this week suggests that extreme weather linked to climate change might be much harder on native species than on nonnative ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: Kentucky: How to Vote, Where to Vote and What’s on the Ballot
description: The governor’s race is the state’s marquee contest on Tuesday.
content: [Here’s how to vote in Ohio, New York, New Jersey, Mississippi, and Virginia.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Beil
title: Gazing Into the Past and Future at Historic Observatories
description: As ever-larger telescopes are launched into space or built at high-altitude sites, these observatories still have wonders to share with visitors and astronomers alike.
content: At the top of Mount Hamilton, near San Jose, Calif., Lick Observatory looks out over the dense sprawl of the San Francisco Bay Area. On a clear day from the 4,200-foot summit, you can see San Francisco to the north, as well as the entrance to Yosemite Valley, 120 miles east, as the crow flies. At night you can see even farther — millions of light-years into space.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 7, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 7, 2023.
content: A quotation highlighted in an article on Sunday about injuries suffered by U.S. troops who  fired vast numbers of artillery rounds against the Islamic State misidentified the speaker, a former gunner who killed a man during a psychotic episode. It was Brady Zipoy,  not Austin Powell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Climate Protesters Damage a Celebrated Velázquez Painting in London
description: For over a year, climate activists in Britain have performed stunts in museums to draw attention to their cause. They’ve often damaged frames, and now appear to have damaged a painting, too.
content: When the suffragist Mary Richardson walked into the National Gallery in London with a concealed hatchet in March 1914, she headed for the “Rokeby Venus,” one of Diego Velázquez’s most celebrated paintings, and slashed it repeatedly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker
title: Gun Law Before Court Is Most Often Used as a Deterrent
description: In the past 25 years, people who tried to buy guns at gun stores were rejected because of having active protection orders about 78,000 times, according to the F.B.I.
content: The federal law at the heart of a major Supreme Court case that could help determine the scope of gun rights in the United States deals with one of the country’s most vexing problems. While the statute has not been used to prosecute a substantial number of people subject to domestic violence orders who are carrying guns, its greatest effect has been as a deterrent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: A Rap Comedy Hits the Road
description: Syreeta Singleton, the showrunner of the Max sitcom “Rap Sh!t,” discusses why the show’s aspiring rap stars are going on tour in the new season.
content: When “Rap Sh!t” premiered in July 2022, the sitcom embraced Miami’s Black cultural landscape, as well as the recent female MC renaissance, with a rags-to-slightly-nicer-rags tale of two locals chasing a hip-hop dream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Consumer Bureau Seeks to Supervise Digital Payment Apps
description: A proposed rule would subject Google, Apple, PayPal and other digital wallet providers to the same scrutiny that banks face.
content: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau wants to extend its watchdog powers to cover digital wallets and payment apps run by companies like Apple, Google, PayPal and Block, which do not have traditional banking operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Wednesday Briefing: Israel Plans a Long-Term Role in Gaza
description: Plus, China shifts the focus of its lending.
content: As the Israeli military campaign against Hamas entered its second month, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu offered some indication of Israel’s plan for the war’s aftermath. He said that Israel will need to oversee the security of the Gaza Strip once the fighting is over to prevent future attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: ‘This Recipe is WOW!’
description: Emphasis reader’s own for Melissa Clark’s five-star coconut curry chickpeas with pumpkin and lime.
content: I’ve been on a chickpea kick lately, enabled by a stockpile of dried chickpeas and Ella Quittner’s extremely thorough guide to cooking them well. Her guide includes pressure cooker times — exactly what I needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: When Will We Have Election Results?
description: It’s not unreasonable to hope for results in a timely manner on Tuesday.
content: It is, of course, impossible to predict exactly when election results will be available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: What’s at Stake in Today’s Elections
description: Also, the Supreme Court suggested it would uphold a gun restriction. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Today is Election Day in many U.S. states. And even though we’re in what political analysts call an off-year — with neither a presidential election nor midterm congressional elections — a steady stream of voters still showed up at polling stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California College Campuses Convulsed in Protest During Israel-Hamas War
description: Two U.C. Berkeley professors who disagree on Israel and Palestine came together to encourage peace on campus.
content: Tensions have been especially high on university campuses since the war between Israel and Hamas began a month ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Israel’s Central Bank Props Up Shekel After Plunge
description: The currency is now back to about where it was before the attacks on Oct. 7, after falling to an eight-year low.
content: The Bank of Israel said on Tuesday that it had spent $7.3 billion to support the shekel, which had fallen to an eight-year low after Hamas’s attack on Oct. 7. The currency is now back to about where it was before the invasion, and on Tuesday was trading at around 3.87 shekels to the dollar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Her Name Is Barbra, but It Wasn’t Always
description: In a chatty and candid new memoir, Barbra Streisand talks about her early determination to be famous and tallies the hurdles and helpers she met along the way.
content: Hello, enormous.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Got Married to Avoid Myself’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Hell is texting two guys whose names start with “B” and trying to keep them straight. Bruce likes the Dead, Giants baseball, my breasts. Bob likes philosophy, books, cats. Bruce has magic hands. Bob loves my writing and showers me with praise. Bruce lives close by, but works an early shift and goes to sleep at 6 p.m. Bob lives off-the-grid in a mountain cabin. I juggle both, seeing Bruce for brunch on Sundays and having long meaningful conversations late at night with Bob. Neither is right, but half of each duct taped together creates a man to meet my needs. — Diane Elizabeth Bouchard
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Mortimer Downey, Force for Mass Transit in U.S. and N.Y., Dies at 87
description: He devised innovative financing to revive New York City’s subway. In Washington, as a U.S. Transportation Department leader, he bolstered Amtrak and secured federal funds for public transit.
content: Mortimer L. Downey, whose creative financing helped revive New York City’s subway system and who also oversaw far-reaching regional and federal transportation policy for more than six decades, died on Thursday at a retirement home in Oakton, Va. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Uber Reports Record Ridership and Second Straight Quarterly Profit
description: Revenue was up 11 percent from a year earlier, helping to generate $221 million in net income.
content: Uber on Tuesday reported financial results that showed its business was continuing to steadily chug along — and even turn a profit — as more riders and drivers used its platform than ever before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Where New York Stands on a Groundwater Crisis
description: Overpumping and depletion of groundwater is a threat to farmers and is even more important because of climate change.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll see how New York is managing its groundwater amid a nationwide crisis. And, because it’s Election Day, we’ll catch up on contests to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Soller and Alexis Armanet
title: A Wood-Lined Retreat in the Heart of Paris
description: On one of the most Parisian streets in the city, two interior designers create a new kind of French fantasy.
content: IN THE CENTER of Paris, in the First Arrondissement, around the corner from the Jardin du Palais-Royal — with its orderly tree-lined promenades — there’s a ragged bistro called Juveniles at which tourists jostle for tables and locals buy bottles of wine to bring home after work. It’s a true neighborhood spot in an office-dominated district where most Parisians could never imagine living, even if they wanted to: Nearby are the Louvre, the Opéra Garnier, Sainte-Chapelle and other landmarks so intrinsic to the grand cinematic vision of the city that the relatively few apartments that become available around here are almost immediately snatched up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: When Do the Polls Close?
description: Voting will end starting at 6 p.m. Eastern in Kentucky, as Election Day wraps up.
content: Polls in states with major elections will close on Tuesday across a three-hour period nationwide, beginning at 6 p.m. Eastern time in Kentucky and ending at 9 p.m. Eastern time in Colorado, New York and parts of Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sasha Dovzhyk
title: I’m a Ukrainian, and I Refuse to Compete for Your Attention
description: Ukrainians have been infantilized by the need to vie for international interest.
content: The day Hamas attacked Israel, I unexpectedly reunited with my best friend in Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Police Arrest Man With Rifle Near the Capitol
description: The U.S. Capitol Police said its officers had apprehended the man near the Capitol and Senate office buildings after a tip from somebody who spotted him walking with a long gun.
content: The United States Capitol Police arrested a Georgia man with a rifle near the Capitol and Senate office buildings on Tuesday afternoon, putting Congress and the Capitol complex on high alert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Ivan Penn
title: How Your Child’s School Bus Might Prevent Blackouts
description: When not driving around, electric buses and other vehicles could help utilities by storing their solar and wind energy and releasing it to meet surges in demand.
content: The four vehicles parked at a depot in South Burlington, Vt., look no different from the yellow school buses familiar to millions of schoolchildren. But beneath their steel shells, these buses are packed with technology that could be vital in the transition to clean energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Ann Hinga Klein
title: DeSantis Lands a Big Endorsement: Kim Reynolds, Iowa’s Popular Governor
description: After saying she would stay neutral in her state’s 2024 caucuses, angering Donald Trump in the process, Ms. Reynolds said “we have too much at stake.”
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida needed a lift in his quest to beat former President Donald J. Trump in the crucial Iowa caucuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: Arab States Intensify Pleas for Gaza Cease-fire as Public Anger Mounts
description: Citing deepening fears for regional stability, Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries are beseeching the U.S. to push Israel to end its military campaign in Gaza.
content: Facing growing anger from their own people, Arab countries are intensifying their appeals to the United States to pressure Israel to implement an immediate cease-fire in Gaza or risk sabotaging the security of the entire Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: ‘Morning in America’ Eludes Biden, Despite Economic Gains
description: Seeking re-election in 1984, Ronald Reagan presided over an economy similar in many ways to today’s. But he sold a message of progress and promise.
content: President Ronald Reagan rode a “Morning in America” message to a blowout re-election victory in 1984, based partly on warm feelings about his economic performance. Today’s economy is similar in many ways to Mr. Reagan’s as he entered that campaign, with one big difference: There is widespread voter angst over the incumbent’s economic stewardship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Seems Likely to Uphold Law Disarming Domestic Abusers
description: A decision in the case could extend far beyond domestic abuse by clarifying the scope of a court ruling last year on gun rights.
content: The Supreme Court seemed ready on Tuesday to rule that the government may disarm people under domestic violence orders, limiting the sweep of last year’s blockbuster decision that vastly expanded gun rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Investigates Birthday Explosion That Killed Military Aide
description: Maj. Gennadiy Chastyakov, an aide to Ukraine’s top commander, died when a grenade given to him as a gift blew up.
content: Ukrainian prosecutors announced on Tuesday that they had opened an investigation into a bizarre explosion at a birthday celebration that killed an aide to Ukraine’s top military commander, in what the authorities portrayed as a tragic accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: A Win-Win ‘Loophole’ Giving Artists Space to Create
description: A London-based nonprofit takes empty commercial spaces and offers them as studios. Artists get a free place to work, and landlords save some money, too.
content: On a recent afternoon, in a ground-floor retail unit in one of London’s many vacant office buildings, a pair of flame-red platform heel boots with what looked like tentacles growing out of them and a multimedia sculpture of a coffin-like object circled by plastic shark fins were on show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: The One Audience Trump Can’t Hoodwink
description: Being in a courtroom deprives Trump of his superpower: his ability to speak without consequence, without factual basis and often without end.
content: The witness stand in Justice Arthur Engoron’s courtroom at 60 Centre Street, in Lower Manhattan, is an ordinary wood-paneled box off to the side of the bench. But for Donald Trump, who is on trial for fraudulently overvaluing his New York real estate assets, it might as well be a cage of kryptonite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Finally, a Make-Ahead Turkey That’s Ready to Travel
description: Whether you’re driving it to dinner an hour away or you just want to plan ahead, here’s the best strategy for a Thanksgiving bird you can prepare in advance.
content: In a perfect world, you’d always be able to serve your Thanksgiving turkey directly after its sojourn in the oven. It’s the best way to take advantage of the bird’s crisp juiciness and meaty aroma — not to mention a chance to hide in the kitchen from football games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Excerpts From Nashville School Shooter’s Writings Are Published Online
description: The publication of the apparent excerpts by a conservative commentator enraged the parents of surviving students, who have been fighting to keep the writings from ever becoming public.
content: A conservative political commentator published three photographs on Monday that appeared to show excerpts from writings by the shooter who killed six people at a Nashville Christian school, enraging parents of the surviving students and prompting an investigation into the leak.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Amid Mideast Violence, Food Can’t Offer a Route to Peace
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 7, 2023.
content: “We have this romantic idea that if we eat the same food and break the same bread somehow we can come together, but that doesn’t seem to be the case here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Why Southern Baptists are Furious Over a Sex Abuse Case in Kentucky
description: A brief filed in a Kentucky case has infuriated members of the denomination across the country, just as it grapples with an abuse scandal.
content: For six months, almost no one took notice of the brief filed quietly by Southern Baptists in a case winding its way to the Kentucky Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Luke Broadwater
title: Special Counsel Rebuts Claims of Favoritism Toward Hunter Biden
description: David C. Weiss told a House committee that he has always had authority over the investigation.
content: David C. Weiss, who negotiated an ill-fated plea deal with President Biden’s son, Hunter, fiercely defended the integrity of his investigation before House Republicans on Tuesday, the first time a special counsel has fielded questions from lawmakers before concluding an inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Vargas Jones
title: Brazil Cracks Down on Surprising New Threat: Neo-Nazis
description: The Brazilian government has raided neo-Nazi groups across 10 states this year, part of a push by the new Lula administration to prosecute far-right extremists.
content: In southern Brazil in July, Laureano Toscani and João Guilherme Correa were smoking cigarettes along a busy road in their prison-issued garb, shorts and sandals, waiting for a ride after seven months in jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Euclid Telescope Dazzles With Detailed First Images of Our Universe
description: The European Space Agency’s premier telescope captured new views of space, a small taste of what it is likely to accomplish in the coming years.
content: Whether capturing spiral galaxies or stellar nurseries, Euclid is showing off our universe’s good side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel McGraw
title: Ohio Votes on Whether to Legalize Recreational Marijuana
description: Medical marijuana has been legal in Ohio since 2016, and nearby states such as Michigan and New York have recently legalized recreational marijuana.
content: While there has been a great deal of attention given to the abortion rights amendment on Ohio’s ballot, voters are being asked another big question: whether they want to legalize the recreational use of marijuana.
source.name: The New York Times
